awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019:  Deciphering the evolutionary dynamics of wild bees in a warming world
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways. The fellow is investigating the environmental causes of recent decreases in animal body size. Across species and the globe, animal body size has decreased suggesting a response to some major environmental change occurring over the past 50-100 years.  This research clarifies what environmental factor is driving this decrease in body size by untangling the effects of two common factors known to affect animal body size, temperature and resource abundance. Additionally, while most studies have not considered if species have been responding genetically to climate change, this study sheds light on whether temperature or resource abundance is causing populations to evolve. Uncovering what pressures organisms are responding to and how they are responding is fundamental to our understanding of how organisms react to rapid environmental change and will affect conservation efforts.

The fellow is combining museum specimens of the native bee Ceratina calcarata from the past hundred years with climate and land use data to reconstruct how bee populations have responded to environmental change.  Since close populations have experienced similar temperature but different land use regimes, a proxy for local resource abundance, the fellow has the opportunity to uncouple the effect of temperature and resource abundance on body size. The fellow is tracking the temporal changes in body size among these populations to see if size correlates with the average yearly temperature or the local resource abundance. The fellow is also using comparative genomics of historical and recent populations to determine if temporal and spatial changes in gene frequencies at areas of the genome identified as being under selection correlate predictably with temperature or resource abundance, indicative of adaptive evolution. The fellow is being trained in molecular genetics and genomic methods, which will expand the fellow's understanding of evolutionary genomics and complement the fellow's background in evolutionary ecology and behavioral ecology. Additionally, the fellow is mentoring graduate and undergraduate students in using biological collections, experimental design, hypothesis testing, and manuscript preparation and publishing, as well as developing inquiry-based science modules in collaboration with local middle schools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This action funded an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supported the research and training of the fellow that utilized biological collections in an innovative way. The fellow has investigated the environmental causes of recent decreases in animal body size. Across species and the globe, animal body size has decreased, suggesting a response to some major environmental change occurring over the past 50-100 years. This research clarified the environmental factors that drive this decrease in body size by untangling the effects of two common factors known to affect animal body size, temperature and resource abundance. Additionally, while most studies have not considered if species have been responding genetically to climate change, this study shed light on whether temperature or resource abundance is causing populations to evolve. Uncovering what pressures organisms are responding to and how they respond is fundamental to our understanding of how organisms react to rapid environmental change and will affect conservation efforts.

The fellow combined museum specimens of the native small carpenter bee, Ceratina calcarata, from the past hundred years with climate and land use data to reconstruct how bee populations have responded to environmental change. Since close populations have experienced similar temperatures but different land-use regimes, a proxy for local resource abundance, the fellow had the opportunity to uncouple the effect of temperature and resource abundance on body size. The fellow tracked the temporal changes in body size among these populations to see if size correlated with the average yearly temperature or the local resource abundance. The fellow found that the small carpenter bee has been shrinking due to increases in temperature associated with climate change but increasing in size due to the increased proportion of the land dedicated to agriculture. These opposing pressures create different selective pressures for each local population and explain why some previous studies that have examined one environmental factor at a time have found conflicting results. The decrease in size associated with temperature may also result in bees becoming too small to survive in agricultural land where large bodies are needed.

The fellow also used comparative genomics of historical and recent populations to determine if temporal and spatial changes in gene frequencies at areas of the genome identified as being under selection correlated predictably with temperature or resource abundance, indicative of adaptive evolution. Results from analysis of the genetic data suggest that bees are responding genetically to land use and climatic factors. Using multiple landscape genetic analyses, some of which account for the population structuring and some agnostic to it, we have identified several single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) that correlate with environmental factors. Most of the SNPs fell within genes with unknown functions, but two of these mutations were immune-related genes. Urbanization and agricultural expansion have been suggested to increase stress on bees due to pathogen spillover from managed and invasive bees. Therefore, these results indicate the aforementioned changes in body size are plastic changes during development and not genetic, it suggests that bees are genetically responding to urbanization and agricultural expansion. These SNPs warrant further investigation.

 

The fellow was trained in molecular genetics and genomic methods, which expanded the fellow's understanding of evolutionary genomics and complimented the fellow's background in evolutionary ecology and behavioral ecology. Additionally, the fellow mentored graduate and undergraduate students in using biological collections, experimental design, hypothesis testing, manuscript preparation, and publishing. The fellow also worked to bring inquiry-based science to local middle schools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
